answers.author: Susan Thorpe
answers.text:
This comes from our Organizational Strategic Plan 
STRATEGIC GOAL #4: PROMOTE SUSTAINABILITY.
The city will position itself as a leader in sustainable actions
Key Outcome: The city will earn regional or national recognition, such as the ICMA Sustainable
Community award, for the organization’s sustainability actions
Strategic Objectives:
a) Design and deliver cost effective services that reduce the impact on the environment.
b) Employ sustainable practices and technologies.
c) Educate and involve the community in sustainable practices.
d) Employ strong fiscal management practices that encourage sustainable fiscal decisionmaking.

This is our definition of sustainability, also from our Org Strat Plan:
Sustainability:  Improving the quality of human life while living within the carrying capacity of supporting environmental, social and economic systems.

answers.author: Brian Wolverton
answers.text:
If you're talking about organizational sustainability, I'd suggest some of the following:
-Turnover rate (which is a sign of an organization's stability, and can be affected by better retention efforts)
-Percent of positions filled through internal promotions (if your organization is good at promoting from within, then it will also be good at building and retaining a knowledge base)
-Percent of operations possessing a procedures manual or manuals (requires identifying each operation- there may be several operations in a single department- that could warrant a procedures manual... and making the development of procedures manuals a priority will go a long ways towards building sustainability)
-Average age of procedures manuals (determine how many years and months it's been since each manual has been updated and come up with an average; encourages keeping them up-to-date, since that tattered manual collecting dust on the shelf from 1977 probably won't do anybody any good)
-Fund balance as % of operating budget (obvious financial sustainability indicator)
-% change in fund balance over last 5 years (to show whether your town is trending up or down)
-% of budget funded by one-time revenue sources
-Debt service as a % of operating budget
-Projected debt service in 5 years as % of operating budget
-Average road condition rating, average age of fleet, large equipment replacement cycle, approved capital budget as % of proposed capital improvement plan, and other capital budget indicators (since cutting back on the capital budget is a common practice by elected bodies that erodes sustainability)
-% of pension liability funded, as recommended by actuaries; % of OPEB liability funded (since unfunded liabilities threaten the long-term fiscal health of an organization)
-% of departments utilizing an up-to-date strategic plan (if there isn't one central plan in place covering all departments)
-Mill rate trends, grand list trends (to show where the community's headed; the government can't be stable if its tax base is in decline)
-Average tenure of town/city managers over the last 30 years (high turnover at the CEO level can be a trouble indicator)
-% of operating budget spent on professional development (like capital, it's something you don't want to see continuously trending downward over time; easy place to cut $$ but the end result is a staff with inadequate training and contact with their peers)
That's what I can think of off the top of my head... if I think of any more really key ones I'll post those as well.  Hope this helps!

author: Pamela Muse
text:
Washoe County, NV is looking to identify definitions and measures in their Strategic Plan for Financial and Organizational Sustainability (as in the ability to maintain opposed to "green" sustainability).
As well, if you have definitions or metrics for community livability, that information would be very helpful too. We appreciate your time and expertise.
Thanks in advance for your help! 
Pamela Muse
Western Regional Director
Alliance for Innovation
888-468-6450
pmuse@transformgov.org
